children.name: when a situation makes it possible for you to do sth
can
children.definition: /kən strong kæn/  ▪ I’ll call you if I can, but I’m going to be pretty busy.can do something▪ Can you come to my place tomorrow and help me move some furniture?▪ I don’t have an appointment, but I wonder if the dentist could see me today.▪ I hope we can find a parking space.▪ You can probably get most of the information you need from the Internet.

children.name: be able to do sth
children.definition: be able to do something /biː ˌeɪbəl tə ˈduː something/  ▪ She was able to get her watch repaired the same day.▪ Because of the drop in stock prices, investors were able to find some bargains this week.

children.name: it is possible for sb to do sth
children.definition: spoken use this especially when you are making an arrangement with someone in order to ask or say what sb will be able to do:
examples: Would it be possible for you to come to a meeting on Tuesday?
It might be possible to use the school library on Saturdays.

children.name: get to do sth
children.definition: get to do something/ˌget tə ˈduː something/  to be able to do something that you have wanted to do for a long time, or something that you are not usually allowed to do:
examples: ▪ We actually got to meet the president when he was here last week.
▪ Do I get to stay up late when Dad comes home from his business trip?

children.name: to be allowed to do sth or have the power to do it
can
children.definition: /kən ; strong kæn/

children.name: ▪ If you want to come with us, you can.can do something
examples: ▪ It’s my house and I can do whatever I want here.
▪ At that time, the king could simply have his enemies imprisoned or shot.

children.name: be able to do st
children.definition: be able to do something/biː ˌeɪbəl tə ˈduː something/  use this especially when a law or rule makes it possible for someone to do something: ▪ You might be able to get a temporary passport.▪ Consumers are now able to buy the drug without a prescription.

children.name: have the power to do st
children.definition: have the power to do something /hæv ðə ˌpaʊəʳ tə ˈduː something/  to be able to do something because your official position gives you the authority to do it: ▪ The judge has the power to order a witness to give evidence.▪ Each state had the power to make its own laws.

children.name: be in a position to do st
children.definition: be in a position to do something /biː ɪn ə pəˌzɪʃən tə ˈduː something/  to have the official authority to do something or have the moral right to do something: ▪ Only the governor is now in a position to stop the execution.▪ Well, given her appalling record, she’s not in any position to criticize my work.

children.name: to make sb able to do sth
enable sb to do sth
children.definition: The money from my grandmother enabled us to buy the house.
examples: The programme is designed to enable young people to find work.

children.name: make it possible
children.definition: to provide the conditions in which sb is able to do sth:

children.name: make it possible to do sth
examples: The direct flight makes it possible to get from London to Tokyo in 12 hours.

children.name: make it possible for sb to do sth
examples: The loan made it possible for him to continue his education.

children.name: make sth possible
examples: I’d like to thank everyone - my family, my friends - who helped to make the whole thing possible.

children.name: allow sb to do sth
children.definition: if a piece of equipment or a service allows you to do sth or lets you do it, it provides what you need to be able to do it:
examples: The web site allows you to order groceries over the Internet.
The telephone service lets users see who is calling before they pick up the phone.

children.name: equip
children.definition: /ɪˈkwɪp/  if education or training equips you to do something, especially something such as a particular kind of job, it prepares you and makes you able to do it: equip somebody to do something▪ The school aims to equip students to deal with the kind of problems they will face in the outside world.equip somebody for▪ Her privileged upbringing had not equipped her for hard work in the fields.

children.name: when a situation makes it impossible for you to do sth
can’t/cannot
children.definition: /kɑːntǁkænt, ˈkænət, -nɒtǁ-nɑːt/  ▪ Look, I know I said I’d come, but I can’t.can’t/cannot do something▪ I can’t go out to lunch today, I have too much work to do.▪ The doctor cannot see you without a prior appointment.

children.name: not be able to do st
children.definition: not be able to do something /ˌnɒt biː ˌeɪbəl tə ˈduː something/  - use this especially in the past or future tense: ▪ She has a meeting with her boss tomorrow, so she won’t be able to come.▪ With everything that’s been happening at the office lately, I haven’t been able to spend much time at home.

children.name: it is not possible for sb to do st
children.definition: it is not possible for somebody to do something /ɪt ɪz nɒt ˌpɒsbəl fəʳ somebody tə ˈduː something ǁ-ˌpɑː-/  used especially when you want to give an excuse or reason for not doing something: ▪ I have a full schedule all next week, so I’m afraid it won’t be possible for me to see you then.▪ We had so many other orders that it wasn’t possible to deliver yours any earlier.

children.name: be unable to do st
children.definition: be unable to do something /biː ʌnˌeɪbəl tə ˈduː something/  use this especially when you want to be polite about the fact that someone cannot do something: ▪ I’m sorry, but Mrs Jones is unable to see you now. Please come back at 6 o'clock.▪ The Pope was unable to attend, due to illness.

children.name: when you are not allowed or do not have the power to do sth
can’t/cannot
children.definition: /kɑːntǁkænt, ˈkænət, -nɒtǁ-nɑːt/  ▪ ‘I really want to see that movie.’ ‘You can’t. You’re not old enough.’can’t/cannot do something▪ The manager can’t fire you for being pregnant.▪ Members of the public cannot enter the building unless they have an identity card.▪ In those days a woman could not divorce her husband except in the most extreme cases.

children.name: not be able to do st
children.definition: not be able to do something /ˌnɒt biː ˌeɪbəl tə ˈduː something/  use this when a law or rule does not allow someone to do something: ▪ If you don’t have a library card, you won’t be able to borrow any books.▪ You won’t be able to get back into the country without your passport.

children.name: not have the power to do st
children.definition: not have the power to do something/it is not in your power to do something /nɒt hæv ðə ˌpaʊəʳ tə ˈduː something, ɪt ɪz nɒt ɪn jɔːʳ ˌpaʊəʳ tə ˈduː something/  to be unable to do something because your job does not give you the authority or right to do it: ▪ It is not in her power to increase your salary, but she can recommend it.▪ Individual states do not have the power to declare war.

children.name: somebody’s hands are tied
children.definition: / somebodyˈs ˌhændz əʳ ˈtaɪd/ if someone’s hands are tied they cannot do what they want because of particular conditions or rules made by someone else: ▪ The company’s hands are tied because of government regulations.▪ I’d like to help you, but you missed the deadline. I’m afraid my hands are tied.

children.name: be out of somebody’s hands
children.definition: /be no longer in somebody’s hands /biː ˌaʊt əv somebodyˈs ˈhændz, biː nəʊ ˌlɒŋgər ɪn somebodyˈs ˈhændzǁ-ˌlɔːŋ-/  if a problem or situation is out of someone’s hands, they are no longer responsible for dealing with it because it has been taken over by someone with more power, or because it must now be decided according to the law: ▪ The matter is out of our hands now - we’ll just have to wait to see what the judge decides.▪ It’s no longer in my hands, I’m afraid - I’ve sent a report about your son’s behaviour to the police.

children.name: not be in a position to do st
children.definition: not be in a position to do something /nɒt bi ɪn ə pəˌzɪʃən tə ˈduː something/  to be unable to do something because you do not have the authority or the moral right to do it: ▪ The agency is not in a position to negotiate or make decisions.

children.name: powerless
children.definition: /ˈpaʊəʳləs/  unable to control or stop something because you do not have the power or legal right to do this: ▪ The average citizen feels completely powerless faced with the rising tide of crime and violence.powerless to do something▪ Although we all thought the decision was unfair, we were powerless to change it.powerless against▪ Citizens imprisoned for their political beliefs are powerless against the government. powerlessness  ▪ For many, feelings of powerlessness lead to complete apathy or depression.

children.name: ineligible
children.definition: /ɪnˈelɪdʒəbəl, ɪnˈelədʒəbəl/  if you are ineligible to take part in something or to receive something, you do not have the legal right to do this: ▪ Police found that many of the people on the list were ineligible voters.ineligible for▪ People with higher incomes are ineligible for the government benefits.ineligible to do something▪ Because he no longer lives in the district, he is ineligible to run for re-election.
